awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Subglacial Antarctic Lakes Scientific Access (SALSA): Integrated Study of Carbon Cycling in Hydrologically-active Subglacial Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
The Antarctic subglacial environment remains one of the least explored regions on Earth.  This project will examine the physical and biological characteristics of Subglacial Lake Mercer, a lake that lies 1200m beneath the West Antarctic Ice Sheet.  This study will address key questions relating to the stability of the ice sheet, the subglacial hydrological system, and the deep-cold subglacial biosphere.  The education and outreach component aims to widely disseminate results to the scientific community and to the general public through short films, a blog, and a website.

Subglacial Lake Mercer is one of the larger hydrologically active lakes in the southern basin of the Whillans Ice Plain, West Antarctica.  It receives about 25 percent of its water from East Antarctica with the remainder originating from West Antarctica, is influenced by drain/fill cycles in a lake immediately upstream (Subglacial Lake Conway), and lies about 100 km upstream of the present grounding line of the Ross Ice Shelf.  This site will yield information on the history of the Whillans and Mercer Ice Streams, and on grounding line migration.  The integrated study will include direct sampling of basal ice, water, and sediment from the lake in concert with surface geophysical surveys over a three-year period to define the hydrological connectivity among lakes on the Whillans Ice Plain and their flow paths to the sea. The geophysical surveys will furnish information on subglacial hydrology, aid the site selection for hot-water drilling, and provide spatial context for interpreting findings. The hot-water-drilled boreholes will be used to collect basal ice samples, provide access for direct measurement of subglacial physical, chemical, and biological conditions in the water column and sediments, and to explore the subglacial water cavities using a remotely operated vehicle equipped with sensors, cameras, and sampling equipment. Data collected from this study will address the overarching hypothesis "Contemporary biodiversity and carbon cycling in hydrologically-active subglacial environments associated with the Mercer and Whillans ice streams are regulated by the mineralization and cycling of relict marine organic matter and through interactions among ice, rock, water, and sediments". The project will be undertaken by a collaborative team of scientists, with expertise in microbiology, biogeochemistry, hydrology, geophysics, glaciology, marine geology, paleoceanography, and science communication.

por.por_cntn:
The Antarctic Subglacial environment is a dynamic ecosystem where life, ice, water, and rock form a web of complex interactions. To better understand this subglacial biome, the Subglacial Antarctic Lakes Scientific Access (SALSA) project employed an integrated approach of scientific discovery, studying the hydrology, geology, and biology of this remote ecosystem. Mercer Subglacial Lake, one of the largest subglacial lakes in West Antarctica, lies underneath the West Antarctic ice sheet, and is about the size of Manhattan and 15 meters deep. During December 2018 - January 2019, SALSA set up a field camp of 50 scientists, drillers, and support staff at a location roughly 800 km from the South Pole. Our team used a hot-water drill to melt a hole through over a kilometer of glacial ice, through which we sampled Mercer Subglacial Lake. Preserving the pristine nature of Antarctic subglacial ecosystems necessitated environmental stewardship; SALSA drilled into and accessed Mercer Subglacial Lake using a clean and sterile system that minimized microbial and chemical contamination to the environment and retrieved samples.

We were successful in documenting the physical properties of the water and the biological nature of microscopic organisms living in the lake, previously hidden in this cold and dark subglacial environment. We also recovered sediment from the bottom of the lake, using coring devices that penetrated to a depth of 2 meters into the sediment. The story of the SALSA sediments transforms our view of sedimentation beneath an ice sheet, with the first ever recovery of laminated lake sediments in addition to previously observed, structureless glacial sediments. Changes in the kinds of sediment observed with depth down core, are thought to reflect changes in overlying ice flow, over time.

One of the overarching goals of studying the microfossils in the sediments was to identify the age and sediment character of subglacial rocks present in regions upglacier from the lake, which are the sources of sediment and ancient carbon feeding into the microbial ecosystem. Microfossils recovered were diverse, including diatoms, silicoflagellates, ebridians, sponge spicules, chrysophycean cysts and palynomorphs. The known biostratigraphic ranges of microfossil species establish two ages for the source materials - about 34-31 million years old and about 5 million years old. This indicates that this region of Antarctica was covered by open marine waters at those times, instead of the glacial ice that exists there today. Notably, we did not observe specimens that are diagnostically younger than a few million years old, even though radiocarbon work indicates that marine waters invaded the lake within the past 10,000 years. This suggests that even if the glacial ice retreated at its base at that time, an extensive floating ice shelf probably existed.

Project analyses were completed with the assistance of an undergraduate researcher. New taxonomic data from this project refines our ability to date ancient samples from Antarctica. Our Education and Outreach program includes a short film series for use by PBS Learning Media, course content for K-12 teachers, and a 90-minute film, The Lake at the Bottom of the World. These products are available to be shared amongst online science communication organizations and science educators.
